text:
Well, welcome, everyone, and
thanks so much for joining. I'm Matt Segneri, a proud
college and HBS alum,

and Bruce and Bridgette
Evans Executive Director here at the Harvard
Innovation Lab. I'm thrilled that
you're all here,

and I personally couldn't be
more excited about today's conversation. Today, March 10, actually
marks the one year to the day

that the university announced
its plans to go virtual. So it's been a year full of
twists and turns for Harvard

and all of the founders and
student alumni teams we serve. I have to say, I'm
incredibly proud of our staff

team who has done amazing
work over the last year. I joined the i-Lab
on March 9, 2020,

so a day before the
university went virtual. And I'll say, on a lighter note,
I marked the passage of time in an unusual way.

I wish it wasn't true,
but I have legitimately eaten 30 pounds of honey mustard
snack out of the snack closet

here in Batten Hall. It was set to
expire, I obviously did it for the common good. But while a lot has changed in
our world, one thing has not.

And that's the inspiring
array of student and alumni ventures committed to
innovation and impact. I've been blown away by what
the entirety of our community

has accomplished. And you can read more
about the breadth of what our teams have
done in the year in review

on our website. Before we jump in with the
incredible Will and Lissy, I wanted to give folks a
quick snapshot of the Harvard

Innovation Labs. We opened nearly a decade
ago in November 2011. I was there on opening day.

And it's amazing to
see how far we've come. We've served 1,700 ventures,
over 3,000 founders,

hailing from 131
different countries. They've raised nearly $3 billion
in capital and impacted dozens

of industries and sectors. We're committed to
this one Harvard vision where we bring all 13
Harvard schools together,

because innovation, as
everyone on this Zoom knows, happens at the intersection of
industries, and disciplines,

and people. We're building a community that
centers equity while taking it on, because it's more
important than ever

to have a truly inclusive
innovation community. What once was just one lab
is now a three-lab ecosystem.

Our student i-Lab, which serves
hundreds of student ventures each year, Launch
Lab X GEO, which

is a nine-month accelerator
program for early stage alumni startups, and then our
Pagliuca Harvard Life

Lab, which serves high
potential life sciences ventures and our fully-equipped
wet lab facility right next to where I
am today in Batten Hall.

These students based in Batten
Hall, while at once might have been at the edge
of the university, it's not an island of
innovation anymore.

It's a thriving innovation
ecosystem across Harvard. SEAS Science and Engineering
Complex is opening this fall,

the Enterprise Research
Campus in Allston comes online in the years ahead. And we have incredible
partners like the HBS Rock

Center for Entrepreneurship, HBS
Social Enterprise Initiative-- my former home-- and efforts at
HMS, GSE, the college, and all

over the university. What's really happening
where the i-Lab sits, it's quickly becoming
at the physical center

of Harvard's campus
in an ascended Allston that's poised to be the
region's next hub of innovation.

The audience today
is an incredible mix of students, faculty,
alumni, staff, other leaders in the ecosystem here
in Boston and beyond.

I'm thrilled to be joined by
two of our incredible alumni founders who are here
in the early days

and have grown
tremendously since. They're inspiring
founders and CEOs, and they're eager to inspire the
next generation of innovators

and entrepreneurs at Harvard. All three of us want to
see even more of them. They've also, as you
saw, hit a special status

in the startup world. They've become unicorns
with valuations of more than a billion dollars. Will is a 2012 college grad and
the founder and CEO of Whoop.

Lissy is a 2014 MD MBA grad and
the founder of CEO and Careport Health.

Rather than just
give their bios, I want to let Will and
Lissy share their journeys. They've obviously reached an
incredible set of achievements,

but they started early days,
like many folks on this call, as not people who would
necessarily call themselves

entrepreneurs. They didn't know
where they'd get to. So what I'll do I'll let
them share their stories, I'll ask a few
questions, and then I'll

open it up to audience
Q&A. So with that opening, let me hand it
over to you, Will, to tell a little
bit about you, Whoop

and how you got to where you
are now, from the college. All right. Well Matt, thanks for having me.

Lissy, it's a pleasure to
be doing this with you. And shout out to all the
Harvard folks listening to this.

I got into this
space, personally, the space of health and
fitness, because I was a college

athlete. I was playing squash
while I was at Harvard. And I was really into
sports and exercise.

And being captain of
the Harvard squash team kind of showed me
that I actually didn't know all that
much about training.

And that got me very
interested in physiology, got me interested in
understanding the human body.

I think Harvard, as we
all know, is a great place to scratch an itch or explore
some level of curiosity.

And for me, that was
doing a lot of research in and around physiology.

And by the time I had
graduated from Harvard, I had read about
500 medical papers

on physiology, which
is to say, what are all the things you can
measure about the human body to better understand it,
especially with an eye

towards performance. And doing all that
research was a little bit

of unfamiliar territory. I was a government concentrator,
I was studying economics,

I had worked in finance
over those summers when I was, say, 19,
20, 21 years old.

But I really had
this itch to better understand the human body and
to build technology to do it.

And so my senior year-- this
would have been fall of 2011-- I committed to starting a
company and founding Whoop.

And today, Whoop builds wearable
technology across hardware, and software, and
analytics that's

designed to improve
performance, improve health. You can see I'm wearing
a small wearable

sensor on my wrist that's
measuring everything about sleep, and
recovery, and strain. And as Matt mentioned, it's
become a meaningful consumer

business. So we started with the
best professional athletes in the world, and today we
serve hundreds of thousands

of consumers. And the journey from the
i-Lab to where we are today

was a pretty fascinating one. I feel quite fortunate
that the i-Lab existed.

So Matt, you mentioned that
it was founded in 2011. We were occupying it,
so summer of 2012.

That's right when I
graduated from college. I had met a guy named
John Capodilupo, who

was Harvard 2014. And I met Aurelian Nicholae,
who was Harvard '12.

And Aurelian had just graduated
and was living on John's couch. And John was a computer
science and mathematician wiz.

He is studying
things like math 55. And the combination of having
a computer science math whiz

and having Aurelian who was
a great mechanical engineer had us well-positioned
that summer.

And so I had a
vision, I would say, for what the technology could
do, what it should measure.

John had a sense for
potentially how we could take on the
algorithm side of it, and Aurelian was a pretty
gifted mechanical engineer,

and he became responsible
for figuring out how we could prototype it.

And that was really
the founding team. And the three of us are still
working together some nine

years later here in Boston. And we went from being three
people that summer, to today,

we employ over 400 people. So it's been quite a
journey from there.

And I'm happy to
answer questions about the whole evolution
from that phase to today.

I think what's exciting
for me in reflecting on that journey is, I
think first of all, how

unique the Harvard Innovation
Lab and also how unique being in the Harvard
ecosystem is as it pertains

to entrepreneurship. It's a group of
people that is coming from remarkably different
skill sets that can then

be united under one roof, which
I believe should be i-Lab, to create things.

And I think that's
really exciting. I remember with great
detail the insecurity

I felt wanting to start
a company my senior year, and seeing all my friends, or
a lot of my friends at least,

going into these high-paying
jobs like consulting, or finance, or whatever else,
and feeling like maybe I

But my sense is that
Harvard, broadly, can encourage its
students across all

these different schools, even
more so to get over that fear. And it's worth it, too, because
independent from how successful

the business ends
up being, the amount that you learn about yourself
in the process of building

a business is truly exceptional. And there were plenty of
times along the period

I certainly wouldn't
have regretted starting the company
because of how much it's taught me about building
a business, building a team,

raising capital, all
these different things. And I think in the
risk-reward analysis

that many students may make in
terms of starting businesses, it's often focused on
what's the outcome going

to be of this business? And it's probably
less so focused on, what's the potential for
the individual in terms

of what you may
learn about yourself or you may be able to develop? And so I know for me and for
the other people, certainly

John and Aurelian who were
there with me from the earliest days of the company,
I know that's it's

been an amazing
journey in that regard, independent from the amazing
success that Whoop has now had.

I'll just leave
you with the fact that it's quite
interesting, also, growing as a CEO over the
course of that journey,

going from managing 15
people to managing 400 people is quite a different change.

And so that's been something
I've really enjoyed. And today, Whoop is now
planning to stay in Boston

as we grow to being thousands
of people over the coming years. And that's another huge, huge--

I think it's a hugely important
thing that the i-Lab has done is that it's made
companies, also,

I believe, stay in
Boston that may otherwise have gone elsewhere. I mean I remember the
senior fall thinking,

oh, Whoop will probably
end up in Manhattan or maybe I should go
out to the West Coast.

But because the i-Lab was
there for those first 18 months and because I was
able to get access to investors, and professors,
and students, and even

sports teams because we were
building technology initially for athletes, it
kept us in Boston.

And so here we are creating
jobs, I think as well, for the city. So anyway, that's a lot of
different things that I've

covered, but grateful to be
here, grateful for the i-Lab, and happy to answer
more questions.

Thank you. I mean, I think you hit a lot
of important themes on that. The team of co-founders you
built as fellow students,

entrepreneurship is anything
but a clear and guaranteed path. And I think the importance
of this institution

in building a deeper innovation
ecosystem in Boston for folks to come and stay. I'll say-- as I told
Will at the top--

I ordered my new Whoop
3.0 strap just last night. I think you're going to get less
of, like, the Patrick Mahomes

high-performance
athlete vibe and more of the suburban dad
in a minivan vibe, but the amazing thing about
this quantified self-movement

is the way in which
all this performance insight around
strain, and sleep, and a whole host
of different topics

makes people more effective
and live better lives. So I think it's a real
incredible company

and contribution. Lissy, I'd love to hear
more about your journey transecting two schools and
building a company that's

seen a lot of its own
share of twists and turns in two transactions over
the last couple of years.

Yeah. And thanks for having me
here, Matt, today, and great to see so many folks were
able to carve time out

of their day to join Matt,
and Will, and myself. And Will, it's a pleasure to
meet you and hear your story.

I have admired your company,
certainly, from afar. So it's great to be on
the conversation with you.

So for folks that don't
know me, my name is Lissy, and I am the CEO and
founder of Careport.

And what Careport does
is we connect hospitals with all of the
services that patients

need after a hospital stay. So think nursing homes, home
health agencies, hospice,

dialysis, durable
medical equipment, just a range of services.

And I started the company
because I was in medical school

and doing the joint
MD/MBA program, and I was training at some
of the Harvard hospitals.

And what I found
was that many, many of my patients coming
out of the hospital

would need some type of care. They would need to go to a
nursing home, for example. And the way that
people have to set up

that care is, there's literally
a nurse at the hospital who picks up the phone, calls
20 different nursing homes,

do you have a bed,
do you have a bed, do you take this insurance,
do you do this service?

And that's the process. And these were at some of
the most technologically

advanced hospitals in
the US, if not the world. And I, myself, would
go home and get on Yelp

and be able to find
information about a restaurant halfway around the
world or book a hotel

halfway around the world. So there just this
huge disconnect where, in the hospital,
you are basically

operating with phone
calls and faxes, and then you would go home and
you would have all this access

to technology and information. And so I set out
to basically build a platform that would
connect these two

different parts of
the health care system and enable them to book
care and to transact.

And at this point, we are in
over 1,000 hospitals, 100,000

post-hospital providers. We process something like 1/3
of the patients coming out

of the hospitals will go
through the Careport system. So we're all over 43 states,
all over the country.

And like Will said, it's
been an amazing journey. But where it started was
the i-Lab and at Harvard.

And I actually
had no idea that I was going to become an
entrepreneur or become a CEO.

This was really just an idea
that I put together for the HBS Business Plans Competition.

And I entered into
it not really knowing what was going to happen.

We won the social
venture track, which was what was called at the time. And then I used the funding
to basically start Careport.

And it's funny, actually,
a couple of years later, after I had laid
capital and was well on my way,

I met somebody who
had won the business competition from years past.

And they were telling me
that you didn't actually

have to use the
money just to start the company, which I thought was
just such a funny thing to say.

But that's what I did. And it's really been the
best decision of my life.

We recently sold
Careport to a strategic

for about a billion three,
which was a great transaction

for everybody involved. And it's been great to, as
Will said, to grow a team,

to lead a team, and to bring
all those people along with you. That has probably been one
of the most rewarding aspects

of building a company
is that, one, you get to deploy a
solution into the world

that you think matters,
that makes a difference. But at the same time, you get
to bring all these people along

with you. And your success
is their success. So I'm excited to have the
conversation today, Matt,

and like I said, sort of
return to where Careport really started.

Awesome. Thank you so much, Lissy. And I think that the piece you
touched on where you go from--

but also in your CEO capacities
responsible for dozens and then hundreds of
people's livelihoods,

success, progress at
your organizations. I'd love to flashback
in time because

for a lot of folks who are
in it right now, who are, maybe they've raised
the seed round, maybe they've just
incorporated their company,

maybe they're still just
coming with an idea, you guys touched a
little bit of on, Will, those early
days in i-Lab, Lissy,

the New Venture
Competition funds. What's most memorable to you
from those early days, when

you look back and
you're like, how did I actually make it knowing
what I knew then, which was--

I don't I want to
go so far as to say, like, you are probably a bit of
a hot mess as an early founder.

But there was certainly
growth potential-- and maybe, Lissy,
you can start on, just what was it like in
the very early, rough days

of Careport? Or what Careport is
now, I should say. Yeah, I mean, candidly,
Matt, it was a hot mess.

I mean, that's
what it feels like. Every single day you feel like,
is this really going to work?

And similar to Will, I
had friends of mine who are going off and
doing all these things,

and here I was driving my car
out to Western Massachusetts

because it was a hospital that
agreed to pilot our solution,

and I was shadowing
nurses around, begging them to let me shadow
them because I was just slowing

them down while I
was shadowing them, so that I could really
observe their workflow and try to figure out, is the
solution that I'm building,
is there really a fit here? And there's so much uncertainty.

I think that was something that
I really had to get used to.

I remember getting
all spun up about, what's the cost of
customer acquisition?

And what's my sales
cycle going to be like? And what is, really, the
revenue model going to be like?

And what I would
say to myself now is, if I were in
those shoes now,

would be that at every
stage of the company you're trying to solve
a different problem.

And at those very,
very early stages, it's OK to not a
lot of those things.

I mean you're trying
to figure out, does my product work for
that particular problem
that I'm going to stop? Is there really a problem here? How painful is the solution?

And is what I'm building
actually going to work? And a lot of those
other things, I mean, it's important
to hold in your mind,

but what I always tell people
is don't be too concerned

about seeing three, four, five,
seven years into the future. Focus on the problem that
you're trying to stop now,

and then, the next
stage of funding, the next stage of your company,
you're going to be solving,

like, a different problem. In the beginning, it was
really product market fit. And then, once I hit a
certain revenue threshold,

it was scaling. I was trying to scale my
operations, my implementations,

my sales team. So you just have to take
it in stages as they come.

Otherwise, I think,
it's just too-- if you're trying to stop--

I think I see a lot
of companies that are trying to stop too
many problems all at once,

and those are the
companies that I think run into trouble and
founders that run into trouble. You really have to focus
and be very deliberate.

And I think that-- before I open it up to Will-- I mean, things you've
both touched on, which I certainly see, and
I think folks on the call

see of sometimes the pervasive
culture of perfectionism, or a sense of being
a fear of failure,

or a sense that there are
certain lanes that people may go down, whether it's a graduate
school path or a consulting

or banking path, that are
sort of well-laid paths that are clear. And the entrepreneurship
one is far more uncertain

because the data show that
most ventures do fail, so there's not a
guarantee of success.

Will, building
software and hardware-- and you shared a little bit
about being instrumental

in building the first
engineering lab as part of the i-Lab-- I'd love to go back
to your early days

when you were finishing up
fresh out of the college. Yeah, the i-Lab was
really in its early days.

I think it was described
as a startup itself, then. And so we were tasked--

because we were the only
company that actually thought it was a good idea
to build hardware, we were tasked with actually
setting up the engineering lab

there. And I remember
[? Nicholae ?] was helping order the different
tools, probably the most

important of which
was a 3D printer. I think we were using
one from Form Labs back then or Maker Bot,
but that was essentially

what was allowing us to create
these really ugly, frankly, wearable devices,
or these massive--

at one point, we
had a huge box that had a cord that
came off of it that attached to something about
three or four times the size

of this that went on a wrist. And this box, then, had to
be connected to a laptop. And so I have funny memories
of, like, John and Aurelian

being tethered to
computers in the i-Lab, because the i-Lab
also got a treadmill. And I think it was more around
a healthy workplace environment,

people should walk
on this treadmill while they're there
doing calls or something, but we actually used it
to do data collection.

Because the first thing that
we were trying to prove-- we're now going back to
2012-- the first thing that we were trying to prove
is that we could measure

heart rate from the
wrist as accurately as an electrocardiogram. And in fact, we wanted
to measure something

called heart rate variability. So to Lissy's point about,
how do you stage out

what you're trying to
prove at any given point, we needed to develop
hardware and algorithms that

proved that we could take
some of these measurements from the wrist that previously
never could be measured there.

And to echo what Lissy
said, I certainly felt a high level of
uncertainty that--

maybe more insecurity. I mean, I think, like,
I was pretty certain that what we were building
was the right thing to build,

but I felt like
every day I was being told we shouldn't build it. The recurring theme that
I always heard was we

shouldn't build
hardware, we should use other people's hardware. And it's funny for how many
years people told us that.

And also, there was a
lot of pushback on why we were starting with athletes. Maybe we should just go
straight into health care,

for example, if this
technology was so powerful. But we had a strong
vision that would grow up

to look like Nike, not grow
up to look like Microsoft. And in fact, the best way
to bring health monitoring

to the masses, was
to have it anchored in upper-end
performance or have it anchored around the
LeBron James and Patrick

Mahomes of the world. And I think there
was a level of what

we were saying in 2012,
2013, that, frankly, did seem too ambitious.

Lissy, I think if
you had met me then, you would have said we were
trying to do too many things. And that was really the
only way I could picture it.

And so I do often
hear entrepreneurs talking about pivoting this
way and pivoting that way,

and da, da, da. Our vision for what the
company was going to be

was really a very straight line. Now, it took a lot of work
to actually build the thing

that we originally envisioned,
but I wrote a paper at Harvard in 2011 titled The Feedback
Tool, Measuring Strain

Recovery and Sleep. I mean, today, literally
what is in the Whoop app is strain, recovery, and sleep.

And that's, like,
10 years later. So we did have a
very strong vision.

And I think that's
probably one of my biases for early founders
is that you want

to have strong conviction in
what the world looks like when the thing is complete. And you also want that thing to
be ambitious enough by the time

that you actually complete
it, it's still innovative. We might able to sit
here and just bat around a few ideas that
seem like great ideas,

but 12, 15 months later,
by the time we actually build it and bring it to market,
six other people have done it.

So those are just some
of the things that come to mind from those early days. The last thing I'll say,
related to fundraising,

the first 700
grand that I raised

was harder than the $100 million
we raised three months ago.

And I say that because hopefully
it gives people some comfort. If you're having trouble
raising a few hundred grand

and you're in the very
early stages, like, it's actually just really hard. You don't have to be discouraged
about the fact you're

having trouble raising capital. I had an enormous amount
of trouble raising capital. And here, Whoop has raised
over $200 million today.

So it's like anything,
it's one, something you have to get
better at, and two, it's also relative to
the stage of the business

and what you've accomplished
or haven't accomplished. And certainly, if you're
younger like I was-- I mean, I was 22 years old
trying to raise capital.

Whoop wasn't just the
first company I started, it was my first job. There's going to be
a lot of skeptics.

And so you have to find a way,
I think, to push through that. And unfortunately, that comes
with a lot of rejection.

So it's interesting
on that skeptic point. I mean, I'm curious. There's a lot of--

I'm sure at every stage of
your respective journeys, there's naysayers or
doubters along the way.

And sometimes the
most plaguing one is when you yourself
are doubting. I know obviously there was a
lot that sustained you both.

On a personal
level, I'm curious, what sustains you in this
work and keeps you motivated? You've been at these efforts
for 7, 10-plus years.

What do you still
find fulfilling? I mean, obviously you're
going up a growth curve. But what sustains you amidst
all that sort of skepticism

and people who doubt what you're
doing, even today, probably?

Well, it feels good to be right. I mean, it's sort of like
you've now been into the future

that you predicted
a while back and you get to actually objectively
see how right you were about that world that
you wanted to predict.

So it feels it feels
motivating to be right about a lot of things
that were, certainly, at a time,

uncertain. It feels good to be,
at least on paper,

making a lot of money for
people who believed in you when everyone else didn't. So that's a really
rewarding feeling

that's kind of underrated,
I think, as an entrepreneur. It certainly feels amazing
to have a large team.

Even though it's
400 people and that seems like a lot
relative to three people, you still have this feeling
like it's against the world.

I think most startups
that emerge successful are still competing with giants.

When Whoop's been written
about in the last six months, it's often been, like,
Apple, Google, and Whoop

will have the potential
within the wearable market, blah, blah, blah. We're swimming with giants.

Amazon literally
met with us and then completely copied our product. That's a trillion
dollar company that's

copying little Whoop that
grew out of the i-Lab. So you still have this feeling
of David versus Goliath.

And that's really motivating. That doesn't get old. Yeah, I would say that,
I mean, I definitely

think as an entrepreneur,
the competition aspect and always wanting to
be better, I think,

for me what's been
really rewarding is, the more you
work on a problem

it's like the more
interesting it gets. Sometimes people say, oh,
I don't know this is--

like, how do you
have a good idea? How do you have,
like, a business idea?

And I think a good
piece of advice for them is you have
to work on a problem,

and if it literally gets more
interesting as you're working on it, then that, at
least, is a signal to you

that this could be something
that you could dedicate-- Matt, to your point--
years of your life. And as an example of that,
when Careport started,

our focus was really
on connecting hospitals with nursing homes. That was the original pain point
that we were trying to solve.

And over time, what we've
seen is that patients need all these other things. They need their wheelchair,
they need their oxygen.

And so being able to
do more, and more, and more for that
patient to make

it a more coordinated
experience for them, I think, has been really motivating. The other piece I
would say is, what's

also great is, in the beginning
you have your core people that just believe in this.

There's no proof
out there enough that they should
believe in this, they just, in their heart
of hearts, believe in it.

And I think over
time that expands. And your vision doesn't really--

in some ways, it's
not really your-- I mean, it'll always
be your vision. But in some ways, it's not
really your vision anymore.

Other people adopt this,
have ideas of where the products should go. And they push the
company forward.

And I think that's so gratifying
to see your mission become other people's mission. And to see them push your
team and your product

in ways that maybe you
didn't even anticipate or didn't really
fully appreciate how that would be executed.

So I would say those are
the two aspects that keep me going years and years later.

I would just add, too, like,
probably the most important thing that's kept Whoop
at-large motivated

is just having a
really great mission. The mission to unlock
human performance

is a very aspirational mission. And we hear from
customers every day

that the product has changed or
improved in one way or another. And that's super
motivating to be

able to build something that's
improving people's health. You both talked about
predicting the future

and anticipating things. Obviously, the last year of
COVID has affected, I'd say,

companies in three
different ways. In some it's propelled. And I think that's
true in your cases, and I want to go

For some, it's been

was the lens through which we looked at COVID-19.

So we started researching

do as much research as we can on this as possible. And so maybe we were a month or

And by early March, we
were the first consumer app to add COVID-19 tracking.

maybe we can inform
our members about it, maybe we could give back to
the scientific community.

By the end of March, we

So really quickly, we had a very

And so we were able to

by the summer, we had published

specific metrics
related to COVID-19 showed up in your physiology.

And the smoking

effectively would jump off the
page if you've got COVID-19. And in about 20% of cases,
it would jump off the page

before you even had symptoms. And roughly speaking, it could
catch about 80% of cases.

So it wasn't perfect, but it was

to the medical community,

So anyway, I've given you that

I think a lot of it is reps.  Especially when I just

And you should try to
listen to what people say, but I think it's important
that you don't zig and zag

with every person that you meet. I just remember so

ended with someone telling
me why I was doing it wrong or I had the wrong

I mean, it really is. And there's no

And a positive way

disagree with you

and you end up being

And that means you also see a

So that gives you an advantage. I guess that's just some

If you hear the same exact
thing over and over again, maybe you want to

think you have to have

strong conviction in the
direction that you're going. Some of the earliest

family, some of it

was from your professional
angel investors. I think as you get on
the spectrum of more

professional
investors, I would just recommend that you try to meet
as many people as possible

and you don't linger. If you're doing a sixth
call with someone, or a seventh call, they're
not going to write a check.

Even if they think they're
going to write a check, they're not going
to write a check. Like, empirically, it
just doesn't happen.

And it's easier to tell

because that's the optimistic

So you can almost always

with what you're doing
